description: Fundamentals of biological chemistry, including the structure of biological macromolecules and their mechanism of action, intermediary metabolism, and the chemical basis of information transfer.
name: PRINC BIOLOGICAL CHEM

values.comments:
This class discusses the fundamentals of biological chemistry, including the structure of biological macromolecules and their mechanism of action, intermediary metabolism, and the chemical basis of information transfer. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 102. Corequisite(s): CHEM 241. 

Students expressed mixed opinions regarding this course. Some students commented that the course was informative and somewhat interesting, while others thought it was too fast-paced, making it hard to “glean information and big-picture concepts.” Another student noted that there is “so much information that the focus of the course is not very clear,” making it hard to study for exams. One student mentioned that the lack of a textbook, sufficient practice problems and a recitation or review session made this class more difficult.

Students also conveyed mixed opinions with respect to Professor Petersson’s teaching abilities. One student described him as being very “brilliant” and “able to convey the course content well (even to a non-chemistry person like me).” A chemical engineering senior wrote that Professor Petersson is one of the best professors in the chemistry department as he is “gifted at stimulating interest.” However, some students stated that Professor Petersson made the material “intimidating” leaving many students “in the dark.” Most people also had trouble getting in contact with Professor Petersson since he “doesn’t have many office hours.” Also, some students complained that Professor Petersson lecture slides and problem sets contained many errors that weren’t spotted only a few days before the assignments were due. A few students were also dissatisfied by the fact that Professor Petersson arbitrarily decided to drop the lower midterm and double the higher one, informing his students on the last day of classes.

The majority of students complained that exams questions were not related to the lecture material and that the exams were too long for the time given. Most students felt that they couldn’t demonstrate their knowledge as the exams were extremely detailed. One student wrote, “The material was presented to us in a very broken, dumbed down manner and then we were tested as if we were graduate students,” with more mathematical problems. However, a few students thought that the exams were “manageable” and fair. One student wrote that “As a non-chemistry major it is very difficult to grasp certain concepts without memorizing vast amounts of reactions.”
